content: This (#11156) is a pull request from @Sophie Morel. I need the content of this PR for a project down stream of Mathlib, so want to push a bit to get it merged.

I have no memory of assigning this to myself (and indeed am not sure I know how to look at what is assigned to me although no doubt it's easy to find out). R The PR has a merge conflict and is tagged please-adopt so the first step is to find someone to adopt it and fix those

How to find out which PRs are assigned to you? In the short term: use github's search feature. You can filter the list of pull requests by assignee also, and then choose your github handle: https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pulls/assigned/kbuzzard.

Medium-term: look at the prototype review dashboard --- bug me again in a week if it's not implemented by then. (I'd like to wait on a pending refactoring to land first, which should happen in the next two days. Showing the assignee this is not hard.)

This PR has been open 10 months. It got no reviews. It depends on another PR, which got some reviews but is also not merged. I concluded that I don't know how to get PRs merged and put them all up for adoption. Do with them what you want.
@Sophie Morel I feel the sentiment. Thanks for replying here.
It's not so much knowing how to get PRs merged, but that the amount of time available for reviews is less than the time needed to get everything reviewed in reasonable time

Well, maybe a bit of both. You opened #11155 on 4 March, it got some comments (last one on 23 March), and you got a merge conflict on 28 March, which it still has. So it hasn't been on the reviewers' radar since then
@Ruben Van de Velde FYI, I just made a push that should be dealing with the merge conflict and build problems.

Ruben Van de Velde said:

It's not so much knowing how to get PRs merged, but that the amount of time available for reviews is less than the time needed to get everything reviewed in reasonable time

I am aware of that, and I am also aware that I do not have the necessary skills to review PRs: I can't say how something fits into the library because I don't know the library well enough, and I can't golf code. I am also unlikely to acquire these skills unless I want to spend all my available research time on Lean, which I am not willing to do.
That being said, preparing something for PR also takes up a large amount of time, merge conflicts pop up frequently and take non-negligible to solve (at least if you're me), and I have many other things that I need to do with my time. You mentioned the March 28 merge conflict, that was the third one, I fixed the first two but at that point I had started wondering whether it was really worth it. I'm not sure what you means by comments, but the PR got no comments from any humans that I can see.

Joseph Tooby-Smith said:

Ruben Van de Velde FYI, I just made a push that should be dealing with the merge conflict and build problems.

This has now past all the CI checks, so if someone can review this - it would be great.

I'm gonna tag @Eric Wieser , because he looked at #11155 before, but please, @Joseph Tooby-Smith , if you have a moment to take a look, please do, that would be very helpful. There's a guide here: https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/pr-review.html
And if it's at the point where you think it looks good, mention that in this thread, and hopefully that'll help get the attention of a maintainer

I have gone through this PR and to me it looks good. This is with the caveat that I'm profoundly dyslexic so I am not the best at these proof-reading exercises.

The only thing I think that perhaps needs changing is the file
Mathlib/LinearAlgebra/Dual.lean could probably be done with splitting up as its getting on to 2000 lines long.
That's probably a good idea, but not in this PR

Ruben Van de Velde said:

I'm gonna tag Eric Wieser , because he looked at #11155 before, but please, Joseph Tooby-Smith , if you have a moment to take a look, please do, that would be very helpful. There's a guide here: https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/pr-review.html

Thanks for the ping, I'll find some time to take a look soon
(I'm out of time for now; since it's tagged please-adopt, I pushed some cleanups, and an ext lemma that I haven't figured out how to use yet)
